Mim, in her work on non-secular computing [117], has made a similar argument around devaluing religious commodities through digital marketplaces. All these tensions create a space for "adverdesign" [50] that we would like to put forth in this work. To make women's labor, struggles, arts, and crafts more visible and to put them in conversation with the modern, secular, and capitalist design, this paper urges the future work to explore HCI design in feminist design methodologies [22,170].

div.head: Regionalization:
div.p: Along with the struggles of the home-based entrepreneurs, our findings surface many spatio-cultural appropriations of F-Commerce activities that happen at a very level. For instance, arranging local support to deliver products/foods/services sold on Facebook, clientelizing through comments on Facebook posts and conversations on Facebook Messenger, developing Facebook groups or pages to initiate supporting mechanisms (i.e. online organizations) for the entrepreneurs-all these measures point toward the necessity of introducing regionalization in design and development of F-commerce's digital features. While decentralization of social networks has gained attention in many branches of social media studies 191], regional appropriation of social media marketplace interfaces is still understudied. In many cases, the universal interface designs for marketplaces fail to grasp the complexities around local/cultural commercial activities. Such phenomena often marginalize the entrepreneurs and their clients [117]. Hence, social media marketplaces, such as Facebook and its associated F-commerce services, need to regionally respond local/regional market economy, market forces, and and shopping Let us provide an example here. One of our participants opines that shopping in urban Bangladesh is a popular group activity. During festivals, such as Puja, and Bengali new year, family members prefer to go to shopping centers and share the fun of shopping together. Family members respect each other's opinions while buying a new dress/ shoe/ home decor items. Younger generations learn how to bargain and buy products considering the family income. With some shops and their owners, families even develop a bonding for generations. Hence, group shopping provides entrepreneurs with an opportunity to build a long-term client base. On the other hand, on Facebook, shopping is an individual activity that takes place through individuals' personal accounts. The current marketplace interfaces do not much scope for a family to experience the group interactions and the fun around group shopping. Entrepreneurs who work hard to develop their client base, also miss the opportunity to build a longer-term relations with their clients and their loved ones.

is a particularly local/ regional aspect that is much different the present-day Western shopping culture, where everything in a shopping center comes with a price tag, one can hardly find any owner/ product maker to know about their business/ products on display, discounts are offered considering the profit/loss calculations-not out of respect toward a generation-long relationship with a client family [34]. Hence, similar to "group shopping" feature, Facebook marketplace should regionally embrace many other cultural aspects around shopping and reflect those in designing and developing interfaces. Design literature in HCI has now long been engaged with such value integration: from Friedman et "value-Sensitive Design" [60] to Le Dantec et al's "values as lived experience" [106] to Houston et al's "values in repair" [80], which needs to be brought in developing this space of F-commerce in the South.

6.2 F-Commerce and Housing Design 6.2.1 Rethinking Development Sequence: Our findings portrayed how our participants are making alterations, additions, or adjustments in their apartments to accommodate various F-commerce activities. We argue that, on the one hand, this phenomenon is forcing local architects and interior designers to do "touch-ups" in an already built apartment to support this new functional demands of the occupants. On the other hand, this phenomenon questions very notion of the sequenced and systematic process of modern housing development. In the modern sequence of development, an receives a land property dedicated for residential purposes (determined by the city land-use plan) as their site of work. The (developer or individual landowner) explains their requiresuch as the expected number of apartments they want for families of a particular economic background, budget for construction, the estimated date for completing the project, etc. After the site visit, demographic and environmental analysis, the architect and their team prepare architectural, structural, mechanical, and fire safety drawings following Bangladesh National Building Codes (BNBC) and submit those to the RAJUK (the public agency responsible for coordinating Dhaka's urban development) for approval. The construction begins right after the approval. Simultaneously, the developers start selling the apartments to their target group showing floor plan types and rendering the architect's team produces. In this sequence, the ultimate purchaser or tenant of an apartment at the very end and has no or minimal voice over the final (apartment) they receive. However, the F-commerce induced re-purposing of spaces is generating a huge "customer-base" for these modern apartments, who do not share a common spatial anymore. Instead, hundreds of business types are creating hundreds of unique spatial demands in apartment design. Hence, voices of the apartment dwellers need to be heard in the design and development phases. The question is where and how, in this very "top-down" modern sequence of housing development, we need to incorporate their voices. Various co-design tools can help conversations among future apartment dwellers and architects/designers [61,152,158]. However, without understanding the political of this sequenced development [23] proper integration of such voices would be difficult to achieve. 6.2.2 Re-evaluating Building Codes: We argue that F-commerce induced re-purposing of also questions the applicability and validity of modern land-use planning that determines which areas in a city will be developed for residential purposes. With the emerging "patches" of F-commerce activities, residential plots are transforming into something else, which might need different kinds of infrastructural support (for instance, increased water supply, uninterrupted electricity, wider lanes or pocket spaces for loading and unloading), and floor area ratio (FAR). Modern building codes also need to be revisited to ensure the apartment dwellers' privacy, and security. We suggest that learning from home-based economic sectors and informal housing might help us to beyond the application mechanism of a set of rules or codes that are not flexible enough to incorporate changes easily (see [9,36,143,177] for example). However, without understanding the trajectories of technological advancement and its appropriation by local communities, architectural or planning interventions would be valueless. This study hence invite HCI scholars, urban planners, architects, engineers, local community representatives to converse, collaborate, and co-create sustainable living and built environments.

div.head: Digital Empowerment and Postcolonial Women:
div.p: the design implications mentioned above, for both HCI and architecture disciplines, our study advances the postcolonial arguments in the design space. Postcolonial HCI highlights how postcolonial subjects interact with the computing systems develin the West, how such interactions often get shaped by their histories of subjugation, and how their local values often contradict with the western values embedded in the computing artifacts or [9,86,169]. In our study, we have seen that the urban Bangladeshi women are trying to empower themselves economically through F-commerce and calling for the removal of the spatial constraints that the modernist architectural design has imposed on However, the question remains: to what extent this advocacy their own voice and to what extent it is shaped by the market that has emerged through the F-commerce platform? one hand, these women, through the newly achieved economic power can bargain with the patriarchal society under the capitalistic system, which in turn, as our findings demonstrate, allows them to make some small changes to their household living condition. On other hand, that very economic power is dependent both upon liberty they may achieve through the architectural freedom that their living condition allows at the present, and the flexibility they get on the Facebook interface. This interesting relationship architectural liberty and digital empowerment points to the underlying larger issue of suppressing women's voice in design -both in modernist architecture and in the capitalist digital market. A narrative of this complexity might boil down to the statement a woman is only so much powerful in changing the oppressive modernist architecture as much the neoliberal digital F-commerce market is allowing her to be. This tension demonstrates a classical contention in the study of South Asian feminism [111], Islamic feminism [38], Chicana feminism [12], and many other non-western feminist movements.
context of the postcolonial South Asian women is well depicted in Gayatri Spivak's seminal work, "Can the subaltern speak?" [162],

the colonized woman is forced to make a choice between liberation and traditional oppression, neither of which she admires. Similarly, our study demonstrates how one modernist economic system-F-commerce, with its speed, scale, rationales, and pragmatic concepts, is replacing another colonial modern Utopian vision around the housing system in the Global South. A large number of Bangladeshi women, with a hope to break the shackles of economic dependency and deprivation, are becoming entrepreneurs the platforms like Facebook, only to find themselves the subject of their problematic surveillance, algorithmic biases, and media manipulation. And thus, the true 'empowerment' of a postcolonial woman in urban Bangladesh still remains a dream to them. To end, our paper invites both the future HCI and Architecture researchers to further explore this tension and help the "subalterns" of our study-the women entrepreneurs in Bangladesh, seek their

div.head: LIMITATIONS AND CONCLUSION
div.p: Our study only concentrates on Dhaka and its urban culture around architecture and F-commerce. Other big cities like Chittagong, Khulna, Rajshahi, and Barishal are also involved in F-commerce, our study did not cover. Moreover, the adoption and response F-commerce in rural neighbourhoods were also beyond the of this paper. We have studied only the formal, modern apartment housing buildings and complexes. This study did not include the impact of F-commerce activities on the bungalow houses of the wealthy neighbourhoods or the informal slums. We acknowledge the findings might reveal new information there. We also have not discussed the complexities and confusions around formalization and taxation [5] of F-commerce and its potential impact on Facebook users and their business models. We did not include the stories around the complex supply chains of the products that our participants were selling on Facebook. The gendered lens throughout the study might exclude the experiences of the other genders around F-commerce and urban housing. Hence, we refrain from any generalization of our findings beyond the studied setting. We rather focus on the significance of such empirical studies in depth of data and richness of details. By using critical interpretive tools our study, we presented a deeper understanding of the practices our field. We hope to expand and deepen our findings and contribution to HCI research with an extended engagement with the communities in future.
